Article Title: The Direct and Indirect Costs of Food-Safety Regulation
Abstract: The compliance costs of the Pathogen Reduction Hazard Analysis Critical Control Program (PR/HACCP) rule have been controversial. Previous reports have used limited data to evaluate its overall and component costs. This paper addresses those deficiencies by examining compliance costs with data from a national survey of meat and poultry plants. Results indicate that (a) regulation favors large, more specialized plants over small, diversified ones, (b) private actions incur considerable costs, and (c), except for chicken slaughter, Federally mandated processing tasks are 160-500% more costly than allowing plants to meet standards using whatever food-safety technology they choose.

Authors: Pacheco, V; Pires, EA; Pizzo, JCM; Willrich, AFG; Banno, LT; de Oliveira, TA
Author Full Names: Pacheco, Vicente; Pires, Eder Alexandre; Machado Pizzo, Joao Claudio; Grecco Willrich, Amanda Fabricio; Banno, Liliane Tiemi; de Oliveira, Taimara Apolonio
Article Title: Management results in agriculture: the storage process as a marketing strategy.
Author Keywords: Seasonality; Storage. Agribusiness; Opportunity costs
Abstract: This work contributes through a case study, with the analysis of the adoption of storage for speculation as a strategy for marketing of agricultural products, particularly coffee. The analysis was based on data collected in a company's branch of the city's General Store Londrina, Parana State. It took into account the effect of seasonality in product sales prices, storage costs and also applied the concept of opportunity cost, a concept of great value for the determination of long-term strategies. In the development of this work it was possible to compare results according to the techniques and concepts defined in the literature. The outcome of the sale was compared in the harvest season with the result in storage of the product from harvest to the off-season, at which time the price was more favorable. The advantages of the method of agribusiness are evidenced thorough results warning about the risks of agribusiness. It concludes that from the use of technical and financial management, you get a more precise result to support decision making. Finally, it recommends the producer to consider other variables in the strategy of marketing of agricultural products.

Authors: Süptitz, LAS; Wobeto, MCR; Hofer, E
Author Full Names: Siedleski Sueptitz, Luciane Andrea; Rhoden Wobeto, Marciani Carla; Hofer, Elza
Article Title: Management costs in pig farming: a case study.
Author Keywords: Costs; Pig Farming; Results
Abstract: This research aims to draw up a case study about the importance and benefits that Cost Accounting provides for rural activity. The research was carried out in two pig properties: one active in the initial cycle, and another in the course of fattening. Data were collected from March to August 2007. The costs and results were made in the researched properties. In the presented results to the pig farmers, it was emphasized the importance of accounting for planning, budgeting, control and management of aid activities. The results showed profit in the initial activity, however, the fattening activity showed a rate of 8.91% of loss in relation to gross revenue. Thus, it appears that only the pig farmers who have financial stability, due to other sources of income are keeping the activity of fattening. Therefore, control and reduce costs without compromising the production is of extreme importance. Accordingly, through the use of Cost-Accounting, there was the economic and financial performance, thus prioritizing, decision making through an efficient administration, and consequently maximize the profits of the activity.

Authors: Dill, RP; de Souza, FC; Borba, JA
Author Full Names: Dill, Rodrigo Prante; de Souza, Flavia Cruz; Borba, Jose Alonso
Article Title: A proposal of a portfolio optimization model for the summer cultures.
Author Keywords: Optimization; Portfolio Theory; Agribusiness
Abstract: The objective of this study is to propose a model that uses the linear programming applied the Markowitz's Portfolio Theory (1952) for aid in the taking of decision regarding of summer cultures portfolio (soy, maize and sunflower) in an agricultural company. For the achievement of the objective, interviews and based documentary analysis in countable information had been carried through so that it was possible esteem the yield of each culture. After that, the historical series of prices between 2000 and 2005 of each one of the cultures was searched to calculate the correlation and in agreement risk the methodology proposal for the Portfolio Theory. Finally, with the aid of software, the function-objective was defined for identification of the portfolio with lesser risk and the biggest possible yield - given the restrictions. The results had demonstrated that, amongst the analyzed cultures of summer, the one that the best yield presented it was of the sunflower, followed of the maize and the soy. On the other hand, the culture of the sunflower was the one that presented the biggest risk. Moreover, the applicability of the considered model can be evidenced, a time that the same contemplates crucial aspects in the choice of the portfolio of summer cultures.

Author Full Names: Hilmer, Christiana E.; Lusk, Jayson L.
Article Title: Determinants of Citations to the Agricultural and Applied Economics Association Journals
Abstract: This paper investigates citations to articles published in the Review of Agricultural Economics and in the American Journal of Agricultural Economics to better understand the impact of articles published in these journals and to evaluate recent policy decisions made by the Agricultural and Applied Economics Association. The biggest factors affecting non-self citations are self-citations and whether the article received at least one citation in the year after publication, suggesting that advertising and signaling play important roles in the extent to which a paper is cited. Principal papers and comments/replies are associated with significantly fewer citations for both journals.

Authors: Rejesus, RM; Palis, FG; Lapitan, AV; Truong, TNC; Hossain, M
Author Full Names: Rejesus, Roderick M.; Palis, Florencia G.; Lapitan, Aileen V.; Truong Thi Ngoc Chi; Hossain, Mahabub
Article Title: The Impact of Integrated Pest Management Information Dissemination Methods on Insecticide Use and Efficiency: Evidence from Rice Producers in South Vietnam
Abstract: This article examines the impact of two Integrated Pest Management information dissemination approaches on insecticide use and efficiency of Vietnamese rice farmers. Specifically, we investigate the impact of Farmer Field Schools (FFS) and No Early Spray (NES) mass media campaigns by utilizing econometric approaches that control for endogeneity and selection problems. Our results suggest that farmers exposed to FFS and NES information are more technically efficient than control farmers who have not been exposed to information from FFS or NES. However, only FFS farmers, not NES farmers, seem to have significantly reduced their insecticide use relative to non-FFS or non-NES control farmers.

Article Title: The Empirical Distribution of the Costs of Revenue-Based Commodity Support Programs-Estimates and Policy Implications
Abstract: This paper demonstrates how the density function of the U.S. domestic commodity support payments for corn differs between current price-based approaches to support and a revenue-based alternative. Comparing across program scenarios that provide equal expected levels of support at the national level, the revenue-based scenario exhibits a lower variability around total expected annual payments, and perhaps more importantly, a lower probability of high payments than the current-style support. Furthermore, for the vast majority of corn-producing counties in the United States, the coefficient of variation of total gross revenue per acre is lower under the revenue-based support scenario than under the current-style scenario.

Article Title: Choice of Coordination Mechanism in the Kenyan Fresh Milk Supply Chain
Keywords Plus: MARKET PARTICIPATION; TRANSACTIONS COSTS; CONTRACTS; BEHAVIOR; MODEL
Abstract: This paper examines the nature and determinants of coordination mechanisms used in the Kenyan fresh milk supply chains, using recent survey data of market participants from Nakuru and Nyandarua districts in Kenya. Three main contractual arrangements are observed in the fresh milk supply chain. These include spot markets, verbal contracts and written contracts. The empirical results indicate that though written contracts are sparingly used in the milk transactions, milk producers are more likely to adopt such contracts compared to traders. The results also show that location of producer, source of market information, distance to markets, travel time to buyers or suppliers, gender of operator, and presence or absence of enforceable contracts significantly influence the type of coordination mechanism used in both producer-buyer and retailer-seller transactions and travel time to milk suppliers.

Authors: da Costa, ML; Dorr, AC; dos Reys, MA; Strassburger, R
Author Full Names: da Costa, Maykell Leite; Dorr, Andrea Cristina; dos Reys, Marcos Alves; Strassburger, Rubia
Article Title: Strategies Adopted by Agro-Industry Complex of Soybean Players in Paraguay
Author Keywords: Agribusiness; Agro-industrial Complex; Strategies
Abstract: The concept of agro-industrial complex (AIC) arises in the 1950s in central countries, as a result of studies on the contribution of agricultural activities in inter-sector relations. Regarding the socio-economic importance of Soybean Complex for Paraguay, this research intended to examine the strategies adopted by major players participating in the AIC of soy in the region of Alto Parana, Paraguay. The survey was conducted through bibliographic review, primary data analysis and field searches. The work provided a systemic vision of the sector, pointing the main stakeholders concerned, relationships between agents, flow of goods and services in various stages of the complex and delineation of scenarios. The strategy used by organizations to minimize the risks is the agricultural insurance, which is mandatory to rural producers in order to be able to access credit. It is important to pick out that this credit is private, facing the absence of the public sector in the financing of agriculture in the country. Based on the results, one can say that organizations operating in Agro-industrial Complex of Soybeans in the region of Alto Parana-Paraguay have well-defined strategies and that they organize themselves efficiently, both agricultural production as the flow of goods and services.

Authors: Gunderson, MA; Lusk, JL; Norwood, FB
Author Full Names: Gunderson, Michael A.; Lusk, Jayson L.; Norwood, F. Bailey
Article Title: Getting Something from Nothing: An Investigation of Beef Demand Expansion and Substitution
Abstract: A relative increase in demand for one type of beef can have one of two potentially countervailing effects: it can cause substitution of one type for another and/or it might expand overall demand. The results of a random parameters logit analysis indicate that regardless of whether USDA Choice or upgraded steak demand increases, the expansion effect dominates the substitution effect. We also show that, for our sample of consumers, the introduction of a new natural steak causes a greater reduction in market share for USDA Choice beef than ungraded beef. Despite this result, however, overall steak demand increases.

Author Full Names: Silva, Marcelo Gois; Scarpin, Jorge Eduardo
Article Title: Disclosure policy management costs by listed companies on the Bovespa: meat and meat products segment
Author Keywords: Cost Management; Meat and Meat Products; Notes; Reports of Directors
Abstract: Different branches of activities are exposed to daily pressures, pressures that permeate activities, processes, decisions. In this context a number of emerging requirements for the use of technical support to the management process can be developed within the parameters which have as their objective the profit and the consequent expansion of the entity and its shareholders. Knowing how costs behave is useful to managers for a variety of purposes because it allows managers to provide the profits when the production volumes and sales change. Agribusiness in Brazil has its own importance, the reinvigorated performance of the agricultural sector, witnessed by record harvests and strong export expansion, has made major contribution to the resumption of growth of the Brazilian economy under the MAP (2008). Thus this study aims to identify what are the evidenciacoes in Notes to Financial Statements and the Reports of Directors of the policy costs for companies classified by Bovespa, the consumer staples sector, processed food sector in particular meat and derivatives. This research is classified as descriptive in relation to the goal, when the procedure document and how to address the problem qualitatively. The study found generally that companies Segment Economic and Meat Products, aim of the study, little evidence of policies to manage costs by limiting in many cases the costing method for measuring inventories.

Authors: Diekmann, F; Loibl, C; Batte, MT
Author Full Names: Diekmann, Florian; Loibl, Caezilia; Batte, Marvin T.
Article Title: The Economics of Agricultural Information: Factors Affecting Commercial Farmers' Information Strategies in Ohio
Keywords Plus: EXTERNAL SEARCH; INTERNET; MODEL; PREFERENCES; ADOPTION; SERVICE; IMPACT; FLOW; SOIL
Abstract: Information-seeking behavior is one of the most enduring subjects in the marketing and agribusiness literature. Based on a mail survey of 3,000 randomly selected farmers in Ohio, this study contributes empirical evidence about differences in farmers' information strategies regarding type, amount, and sources of information, and identifies factors that explain the variation in farmers' information search behavior. Farmers split into four distinct search typologies. Farmers' attitudes toward search, farm sales, years farming, Internet access, and farm type were good predictors of search strategies, underscoring the value of the clustering approach for farmer segmentation.

Authors: McFadden, DT; Umberger, W; Wilson, J
Author Full Names: McFadden, Dawn Thilmany; Umberger, Wendy; Wilson, Joshua
Article Title: Growing a Niche Market: A Targeted Marketing Plan for Colorado Homestead Ranches
Abstract: Colorado Homestead Ranches is one of a number of emerging value-added agricultural enterprises exploring the use of direct marketing to improve profitability and manage the risk inherent in commodity markets. This case study presents the market analysis and marketing channel information they used in developing a strategic marketing plan that includes a focus on consumer interest in production practices, willingness to pay for differentiated beef products and food purchase behavior as they explore further expansion of their business. Students are encouraged to consider targeted marketing strategies and the advantages and disadvantages of various marketing channels available to value-added producers.

Author Full Names: Bishop, Clark P.; Shumway, C. Richard
Article Title: The Economics of Dairy Anaerobic Digestion with Coproduct Marketing
Abstract: Increasing national focus on renewable energy has prompted a reappearance of anaerobic digestion technology installations on dairy farms. The focus of this study is on an operational digester in Washington State. Using the first two years of physical and financial data from the operational digester, a base scenario is constructed. The analysis focuses on the impact of developing various coproduct markets on the digestion system's feasibility. The coproduct markets analyzed include electricity, digested fiber, tipping fees, and carbon credits. The results of the economic analysis show that tipping fees and electricity are key revenue sources for the digester.

Article Title: A Place for Water Markets: Performance and Challenges
Keywords Plus: VIRTUAL WATER; NORTH CHINA; POLICY; IRRIGATION; EFFICIENCY; AGRICULTURE; TRANSFERS; RIGHTS; EXTERNALITIES; REALLOCATION
Abstract: The 2006 United Nations Human Development Report paints a dismal picture of global water scarcity and the increasing pressures on agricultural water supplies. While it acknowledges that demand-side policies are more effective than supply-side approaches, it remains skeptical of water markets as a means of managing scarce water supplies. This contrasts sharply with the successful implementation of water markets within the United States and other countries. To clarify the debate, this article evaluates the performance of established water markets. It also considers different challenges posed by water markets in developed and developing countries and discusses how countries can overcome these challenges.

Authors: Roosen, J; Marette, S; Blanchemanche, S; Verger, P
Author Full Names: Roosen, Jutta; Marette, Stephan; Blanchemanche, Sandrine; Verger, Philippe
Article Title: Does Health Information Matter for Modifying Consumption? A Field Experiment Measuring the Impact of Risk Information on Fish Consumption
Abstract: A field experiment was conducted in France to evaluate the impact of health information on fish consumption. A warning revealed the risks of methyl mercury contamination in fish and gave consumption recommendations. A difference-in-differences estimation shows that this warning led to a statistically significant but relatively weak decrease in fish consumption. Consumption of the most contaminated fish did not decrease despite advice to avoid consumption of these fish. Accompanying questionnaires show that consumers imperfectly recall the fish species quoted in the warning. The results suggest a relatively poor efficacy of a complex health message, despite its use by several national health agencies.

Authors: de Souza, MP; de Souza, TA; Muller, CAD; de Souza, DB
Author Full Names: de Souza, Mariluce Paes; de Souza Filho, Theophilo Alves; da Silva Muller, Carlos Andre; de Souza, Dercio Bernardes
Article Title: Costs of production in rural milk producing units: evaluation of management and productivity
Author Keywords: Management; Costs; Milk; Productivity
Abstract: The assessment of operating costs leads decision-making aimed at increasing productivity. As a result of technical progress in agriculture charge of agricultural production is in the hands of capital, increasingly sharpening competitiveness. This approach refers to the understanding of the production chain in order to demonstrate how the activities are developed in the gate in the production unit. The survey is of a quanti. Forms were applied in order to obtain data to support analysis. The respondents were dairy farmers in Rondonia an association - the Amazon region. The results indicate that productivity is low, the units of rural production have little information and management decisions often are related to different aspects of economic rationality. With regard to production costs, although not very high, are not directly related to better management decisions are often related to underutilization of resources needed for the activity.

Author Full Names: Foltz, Jeremy D.; Barham, Bradford L.
Article Title: The Productivity Effects of Extension Appointments in Land-Grant Colleges
Abstract: This article analyzes the primary activities of agricultural college faculty with and without extension appointments using survey data. The evidence suggests that differences between extension professors and others in agricultural colleges in terms of research production are small for minor extension appointments, but show significant and increasing trade-offs between extension and research outputs above a 40% extension appointment. The evidence is broadly suggestive of the potential for gains from exploiting complementarities between extension and research rather than from pursuing high levels of specialization. The work concludes with implications for the role of state specialists in Cooperative Extension.

Article Title: US Dairy Industry Supply Control: Managing the Cooperatives Working Together Program
Abstract: One common approach many agricultural industries have pursued is supply control to balance supply and demand. For this purpose, U.S. dairy farmers have developed the Cooperatives Working Together (CWT) program. To achieve a supply control objective, CWT reduces cow numbers and funds dairy product exports. This case focuses student understanding on program effectiveness in light of changing dairy economic conditions. Students can be challenged to understand how supply removal impacts price through applying elasticity estimates. An appendix, designed for case teachers, is available at Ag Econ Search, http://ageconsearch.umn.edu.

Article Title: Strategy-Structure Alignment in the World Coffee Industry: The Case of Cooxupe
Abstract: This case discusses the evolution and challenges of Cooxupe-a coffee marketing cooperative in Brazil. Founded in 1954 by twenty-four producers, Cooxupe experienced significant growth since 1990 as a result of direct export efforts implemented by Joaquim, the Export Director. Yet Cooxupe leaders face increasing challenges ahead. The world coffee industry has evolved in such a way that growth is deemed essential for survival. The growth imperative poses additional challenges to Cooxupe. First, it becomes more difficult to originate coffees with the quality consistency expected by clients. Second, the increased size and heterogeneity of the membership may have negative impacts on cohesion. Third, financial constraints create the need to evaluate and possibly change the cooperative ownership structure.

Authors: Pereira, SM; Lobo, DD; da Rocha, WF
Author Full Names: Pereira, Sandra Mara; Lobo, Debora da Silva; da Rocha, Weimar Freire, Jr.
Article Title: Costs and analysis of investment to transport pig manure with subsequent generation of bioenergy in the city of Toledo-PR
Author Keywords: Transportation costs; Pig manure; Bioenergy
Abstract: The work addresses the theme analysis of costs and investments for the collection of pig manure (in the finishing phase) in rural properties in the city of Toledo, with the final destination a center of bioenergy. The theoretical base includes agribusiness topics, transportation costs and investment analysis; characterization of swine production site. In the methodology, collected information is related to properties with 380 pigs in the finishing stage, performing with the aid of heuristic routing of Clark & Wright. Were researched information on vehicles and equipment used in this activity, operating costs and investment for the acquisition of them, as well as for the establishment of a center of biodigestion. We analyzed the potential to generate waste, biogas and electricity and the quantities of pigs in the properties searched. For the implementation of the project will require major investments, however, profitability with the sale of biogas and electricity compensate. It follows that it is feasible to implement a similar project, for the benefit of farmers, who will have new source of revenue with the sale of pig slurry, providing a new energy matrix, using a highly waste polluter, and preserve the environment, not suffer the dump indiscriminate of pig manure

Author Full Names: Zamberlan, Carlos Otavio; Zamberlan, Joao Fernando
Article Title: Systems of costs in agribusiness: a Study in the area of the Fourth Italian Colony
Author Keywords: Small companies; Costs systems; Costing methods
Abstract: It is important for companies to be structured as to face the great competition of the contemporary world, independent of its size. Financial accounting, even when recognized for its vital importance to records and controls, is not so used as a managing tool. Having set this stage, it becomes important to check the relevance given to costs systems by the small companies, once the lack of its use may cause the companies to be vulnerable to the global competition. This work proposes to analyze whether the small entrepreneur from production units of fruits and vegetables and colonial products from the 4(th) colony, RS state, realize how relevant it is to take advantage of costs systems. This article is characterized as a descriptive research, a survey was done regarding the importance of costs systems along with interview techniques with the regional producers. Data were analyzed by frequency statistics, central tendency and dispersion, with help from the software SPSS 13.0. It was concluded that costs systems are considered to be relevant by the researched producers, though not very utilized.

Authors: Abrantes, LA; Reis, RP; Silva, MP
Author Full Names: Abrantes, Luiz Antonio; Reis, Ricardo Pereira; Silva, Maisa Pereira
Article Title: The indirect taxation on costs of the coffee production and commercialization.
Author Keywords: Taxation. Coffee; Indirect Taxes
Abstract: The coffee activity has been representing great economical and social importance to Brazil, mainly to Minas Gerais State. Because the competitiveness in this environment, the producers look for alternatives to optimize the costs of production, that are mainly composed by inputs and labor as well as by incidence of the taxes that will increase the costs of both production and commercialization of the product, therefore affecting economically and financially the performance of the sector. The expenses on the payroll of the labor, ICMS, PIS and Cofins are distinguished among those taxes. So, taking those aspects into account, this work was carried out to evaluate and analyze the taxation on costs of the coffee production and commercialization, as well as to measure the effective load of the taxes composing the formation of the price of the final production and commercialization of the green coffee bean in Minas Gerais. So, the group of agents representing the producer segment in the agroindustrial coffee chain were adopted, by considering the stages of the production process, improvement and commercialization of the products. The assessment of the taxes were observed to be complex due to several legal norms, multiple incident aliquots, different competences (Union and States) besides the cumulative taxation, that affect the producer at acquisition of the inputs and capital goods, therefore burdening the productive process.

Article Title: The use of currency hedging in the Brazilian wheat
Author Keywords: Hedge; Wheat Industry; Exchange; Derivatives
Abstract: The level of volatility that took the currency market presents a series of setbacks for the industry of wheat, mainly due to its exposure to currency risk. About 90% of wheat consumed in Brazil is of external origin, and because it is a commodity is priced in U.S. dollars. Because of this exposure, it is mister, that the industry adopt a stance of protection (hedging) in order to eliminate possible fluctuations in the price of exchange upon payment of purchases. We analyzed the behavior of the price of wheat versus the dollar over the past four years. It was found that, due to oscillation of the price of wheat, it should be hedge to protect such oscillation. There are several tools available in the market to perform the hedges, but they all lead to additional costs for the company you want to buy these hedges. Firms may have hedged by buying dollars or through investments backed by U.S. dollars. However, these tools require a great availability of resources. If the company does not have these available, you can use the derivatives market hedge and seek cheaper. However, because it is a risky market, the company can earn (make right protection) or lose a lot of money if you do not make an appropriate hedge.

Authors: Hooker, NH; Shanahan, CJ; Rake, V; Francis, E; Popovich, C; Dehoney, J
Author Full Names: Hooker, Neal H.; Shanahan, Christopher J.; Rake, Valerie; Francis, Eboni; Popovich, Charles; Dehoney, Joanne
Article Title: A Technology-Enhanced Teaching Tool: Tracking Student Adoption and Performance
Abstract: This article describes a Principles of Agribusiness Marketing course redesign that incorporated an online management system, various electronic information resources including a product innovation database, and individual and group research projects. Using the food industry as the vehicle, we attempt to enhance student understanding of basic marketing principles. Responses to an end-of-quarter technology survey and tracking data from the course management system are applied in a Technology Acceptance Model to determine factors that may influence student perceptions of the course management system's usefulness as a learning tool and performance.

Authors: Roberts, DC; Clark, CD; English, BC; Park, WM; Roberts, RK
Author Full Names: Roberts, David C.; Clark, Christopher D.; English, Burton C.; Park, William M.; Roberts, Roland K.
Article Title: Estimating Annualized Riparian Buffer Costs for the Harpeth River Watershed
Keywords Plus: ECONOMIC-ANALYSIS; FILTER STRIPS; MANAGEMENT; CONSERVATION; QUALITY; STRATEGIES; PLACEMENT; VALUATION; EROSION; REGION
Abstract: Water pollution from nonpoint sources is increasingly a focal point for efforts to reduce water quality impairments. These efforts often require or subsidize riparian buffer strips. However, the costs of these buffer strips are not always well understood. This article estimates the annualized costs of establishing and maintaining 45.7-meter (150-feet) riparian buffer strips on all agricultural land adjoining a waterway in Tennessee's Harpeth River watershed. A mandatory requirement for buffer strips of this width would result in 4,955 hectares (12,245 acres) of buffer strips at an annualized cost of $1.3 million. A supply curve for buffer strips is also constructed.

Article Title: In Search of a Theory of Shopping Value: The Case of Rural Consumers
Abstract: Although the challenges facing rural retailers have been attributed to competition and decreasing population, this paper defines the problem from rural consumers' perspective. It argues that consumers select shopping location on its shopping value, determined by its attractiveness and accessibility. The results indicate that locations closest to the consumer's residence offer the highest shopping value for groceries and other low-order goods. They also show that increasing gasoline prices favor local retailers. Rural retailers may use these results to implement differentiating strategies that increase their attractiveness, accessibility, and consequently their competitiveness.

Article Title: Value-Added Agricultural Enterprises and Local Economic Performance
Keywords Plus: GROWTH; DETERMINANTS; CONVERGENCE; EMPLOYMENT; ENTREPRENEURSHIP; INDUSTRY; STATE
Abstract: Proponents of value-added agricultural enterprises (VAAE) argue for favorable government policies and funds to promote these industries as a local development strategy. Though regularly advocated at all levels of government, the beliefs regarding the benefits of VAAE to local economies merit empirical investigation. A county-level analysis of the contiguous U.S. states for a ten-year time period was used to evaluate the contribution of selected VAAE to county economic well-being. The two-stage least squares regression coupled with spatial econometric methods suggests that the support for these selected VAAE as a tool of local economic well-being, measured using income and employment growth and change in poverty rates, is not well founded.

Authors: Brester, GW; Grant, B; Boland, MA
Author Full Names: Brester, Gary W.; Grant, Brenna; Boland, Michael A.
Article Title: Marketing Organic Pasta from Big Sandy to Rome: It's a Long Kamut®
Abstract: Bob Quinn spent 20 years propagating an ancient Egyptian wheat variety that is generally known as Khorasan wheat. Bob trademarked his wheat variety using the brand name Kamut((R)). Kamut((R)) brand wheat contains some nutritional, health, and taste advantages over modern wheat varieties, but lacks some of modern wheat's agronomic advantages. Kamut((R)) brand wheat is organically produced, and is used to make cereals, breads, cookies, snacks, pancakes, bread mixes, bulgur, pasta, and baked goods. Whole wheat products produced from Kamut((R)) brand wheat are less bitter than those produced from modern wheat varieties. Europe represents approximately two-thirds of the market for this product.

Authors: Harri, A; Erdem, C; Coble, KH; Knight, TO
Author Full Names: Harri, Ardian; Erdem, Cumhur; Coble, Keith H.; Knight, Thomas O.
Article Title: Crop Yield Distributions: A Reconciliation of Previous Research and Statistical Tests for Normality
Abstract: This study revisits the large but inconclusive body of research on crop yield distributions. Using competing techniques across 3,852 crop/county combinations we can reconcile some inconsistencies in previous studies. We examine linear, polynomial, and ARIMA trend models. Normality tests are undertaken, with an implementable R-test and multivariate testing to account for spatial correlation. Empirical results show limited support for stochastic trends in yields. Results also show that normality rejection rates depend on the trend specification. Corn Belt corn and soybeans yields are negatively skewed while they tend to become more normal as one moves away from the Corn Belt.

Author Full Names: Mendonca, Silvia Amelia; De Gregori, Roberto
Article Title: Analysis of the financial risk in agricultural cooperatives of Rio Grande do Sul
Author Keywords: Financial Risk; Universal Doctrinal Principles; Agricultural Cooperatives
Abstract: The risks and uncertainties contained in the business scenario have stimulated the organizations to search an efficient risk management. Thus, this study investigates, within the risk management, a relevant theme: the financial risk. This is one of the themes most dealt by public companies, however, there is a lack of studies in the cooperative sector. Thus, it was necessary to analyze how the agricultural cooperatives of Rio Grande do Sul measure the financial risk, checking on the background the perception of doctrinal principles. The research used a structured questionnaire and case studies. As results, the cooperatives can understand, in general scope, the importance of risk management. However, when asked about the degree of indebtedness, they showed mixed opinions. Therefore, it is noted that the main difficulty of this type of organization is to find, within a capitalist economy, a balance between the social and the economic aspect.

Article Title: Do Government Economists Value AAEA Conferences?
Keywords Plus: CONTINGENT VALUATION; CONJOINT-MEASUREMENT; CHOICE EXPERIMENTS; RESPONDENTS; PREFERENCE; ISSUES; LOGIT
Abstract: This article examines the importance and value of attending the annual summer conference of the Agricultural and Applied Economics Association (AAEA) by U.S. Federal government economists. A choice-based conjoint analysis of government funding of five research-facilitating resources, including travel and nontravel resources, shows that respondents have a clear preference for their government agency funding the travel-related resources over the other resources. Furthermore, using the contingent valuation method, we find that these economists would have been willing to pay $195 to $620 to have attended their last AAEA conference, with the bounds on this range depending on modeling assumptions.

Article Title: The Economics of Soil Fertility Management in Malawi
Abstract: We estimated a normalized translog yield-response model using African farm-household survey data to compare the yield of smallholder maize production under integrated soil fertility management (ISFM) and chemical-based soil fertility management. Controlling for other factors, maize yield responses were higher under ISFM. Results suggest ISFM practices would significantly improve the profitability of smallholder maize production, especially under escalating fertilizer prices.

Article Title: Analysis of the costs involved in the implantation of a winery company in Rio Grande do Sul state.
Author Keywords: Wines and sparkling wines; Unit contribution; Break-even point
Abstract: The mountain region of Rio Grande do Sul state stands out in the national scenery through the potential presented by its wineries, from business prospection related to tourism to the increase in the local economy. In this way, the objective of this paper is to evaluate the viability to establish a winery based in the projected costs, calculating the unit contribution and the break-even point for the products that will be manufactured. For this purpose, an exploratory survey was conducted, with a case-study in an industrial Brazilian company, using qualitative and quantitative data in three ranges of products that will be produced by the company. As a result of this study, all the products were considered to have viable conditions for production and commercialization, bringing satisfactory profitability. As a conclusion, the decision of implementing a winery based on costs contributes for a better understanding of the structures used for this purpose, showing the most profitable products and giving a dimension of the minimum volumes required to obtain the desired results.

Article Title: Environmental costs of soybean in areas of expansion in recent brazilian savannah: the case of Pedro Afonso/TO
Author Keywords: Replacement cost method; Environmental costs; Commodities; Environment
Abstract: Since the decade of 90 with the increase of the soy price in the international market other areas from Brazilian savannah had been incorporated to the soy production. Three cities can be detached in the process: Luis Eduardo Magalhaes - BA, Balsas - MA and Pedro Afonso - TO. This expansion can mean the magnifying of ambient impacts in ground in the water resources, the biodiversity and the conditions of ecological balance of the Brazilian savannah. The study measures monetarily, through Replacement Cost Method, the ambient impacts of soy plantation technologies in the region of recent expansion in the Brazilian savannah, having as case study the city of Pedro Afonso - TO. In the specific region of the study the annual ambient costs of the soy production had been esteem in R$ 2,24 / ha. However, the progressive adoption of more producing for no tillage can reduce this value for R$ 0,61/ha.

Article Title: Evaluation of yield and yield components by different statistical methods in wheat (T. aestivum L.)
Author Keywords: Wheat; Yield; Yield componentes
Keywords Plus: GRAIN-YIELD; DURUM-WHEAT; WINTER-WHEAT; SOWING DATE; CULTIVARS; QUALITY; STRESS; WATER; SIZE
Abstract: The aim of this study was to determine relationship yield and yield components and to show efficiency of components on yield by using different statistical methods on data collected from berad wheat cultivars grown under rainfed conditions. Data of yield and yield components over the two years in the study were evaluated by statistical procedures; the correlation, multiple linear regression, path and factor analyse. Results in the study with respect to four statistical methods leaf area photosynthetic efficiency, green area photosynthetic efficiency, spike number per m(2) leaf area index, grain weight per spike and harvest index were the most important characteristics and they were highly effective on grain yield.

Author Full Names: Capobiango, Ronan Pereira; Abrantes, Luiz Antonio
Article Title: Tax incidence on the cost of production and marketing of milk in Minas Gerais
Author Keywords: Milk; Production Costs; Taxation
Abstract: The agro-industrial chain of milk represents an activity of well-known economic and social participation in Brazil, mainly for Minas Gerais. However, factors such as the cost structure of inputs and capital goods and the tax burden on her, that along the production chain generates a cumulative effect, result in implications that go from the producer to the consumer. The objective of this study was to identify and highlight the tax burden in the formation of production costs for the segment producer of milk and its marketing to different strata of the daily production. To this end, we adopted the construction of an analytical model aimed at quantifying the effect the tax burden. The combined impact of the ICMS, PIS / COFINS and charges levied on the production cost of 3.19%, 4.17%, 4.88%, 5.50% and 5.35%, considering, respectively, the strata costs for the following range of production: less than 50 liters of milk, 51 to 200 liters, 201 to 500 liters, 501 to 1000 liters to 1000 liters and above. At the time of marketing aggregates was also 2.3% more by way of pension contributions that the individual farmer collects on the gross revenue generated by raising the final cost. Production costs, as well as their components and the taxes imposed on them, are important factors that reflect the competitiveness of the entire production chain, and taxation as an aggravating factor in the relationship between the different segments of agribusiness chains.

Authors: Tonett, L; de Souza, VR; Ribeiro, MD
Author Full Names: Tonett, Laura; de Souza, Valdiva Rossato; Ribeiro, Maisa de Souza
Article Title: Benefits of the projects carried out under the premises of a Clean Development Mechanism in hog raising.
Author Keywords: CDM; Credit of carbon; Hog raising
Abstract: The clean development mechanism (CDM) represents an alternative to stimulate the implementation of sustainable undertaking under the economical, environmental and social aspects, through sectors being regarded as potentially polluting. In face of such scenario, this research aims to analyze the benefits which have arisen out of investments in hog raising undertaking. This is an exploratory research, carried out with its base on a documental analysis of a negotiation between two entities, being one a national company and the other, a foreign one, both located in Mato Grosso state. The present study has revealed the existence of a series of advantages that came along with the gas methane treatment generated by the animal's waste. Such advantages include the elimination of environmental impact and its costs, energy production aiming self maintenance, bio-fertilizers production, which are less harmful to the soil and the underground water, with no additional costs. We have noticed the need to create means to identify and measure the referred benefits, targeting to obtain elements to reinforce the demonstration that the cost-benefit relation is positive both the company and the local community. Accounting can potentially assess the process of the economical/financial results of the related enterprises involved in the process and the demonstration of the possible advantages may stimulate the implementation of related business activities.

Authors: Catapan, A; Catapan, DC; Catapan, EA
Author Full Names: Catapan, Anderson; Catapan, Dariane Cristina; Catapan, Edilson Antonio
Article Title: Alternative forms of electricity generation from the biogas: An approach to the cost of generation of energy
Author Keywords: Biogas; Biodigesters; Electric Energy
Abstract: The swine industry has already known for its high production of manure has high level polluter, however, the reversal of the situation, transforming the problem waste in an energy solution, by means of biodigesters, will no longer be a rhetoric, with the initiative of some producers. The present work seeks to study the impact of the composition of biogas digesters in, as well as to present a study of the cost of electricity generated from swine manure. The work was carried out on 3 farms located in municipalities of Parana and included data collection and analysis of the biogas through the use of the kit biogas, developed by EMBRAPA. Also involved the revisions references relating to the environmental problems caused by slurry pigs and the use of bio-digesters for wastewater treatment for pigs. The analysis of the composition of biogas showed that the best medium expected for the carbon dioxide (CO2) and methane (CH4), the main gases of biogas, were respectively 37.58 % (20-40 %) and 62.43 % (60-80 %). The use of the biodigester plays a fundamental role in pig farming current, because it provides the production of biogas with a composition rich gases of great potential generator of electricity.

Author Full Names: Buss, Aline Eberhard; Duarte, Vilmar Nogueira
Article Title: Study of the economic viability of the milk production in a farm located at Mato Grosso do Sul.
Author Keywords: Milk activity; Cost of production; Economic viability
Abstract: The present work had as objective to analyze the economic viability of the milk activity in farm AZ, located in the city of Beautiful Sight in the Mato Grosso of the South, in the period of October of 2007 the September of 2008. The research was carried through through the monthly survey of all the referring information to prescriptions and expenditures of the activity. The methodology used for analysis was the proposal for Marion (2004), that it allowed, by means of launching in electronic spread sheets, to observe the behavior of the returns of the activity to the end of each month. The study it showed mainly that these returns have significant variations of one month for another one, in function of variations in the productivity and in the price of milk. It also showed, that the commercial ration represents the item with bigger weight in the administration fees of the activity. The study it concluded that only the deriving prescriptions of venda of milk had not been enough to cover the administration fees, to bank the costs with depreciation of machines and installations and the cost of chance. But the prescriptions of milk, added to prescriptions of venda of year-old calves and cows of discardings had generated surplus in the economic results of the activity in the studied period.

Authors: Simoes, DQC; Pessoa, MNM; dos Santos, SM; Cabral, ACA; do Nascimento, DC
Author Full Names: Costa Simoes, Dnyse Queiroz; Monteiro Pessoa, Maria Naiula; dos Santos, Sandra Maria; Aquino Cabral, Augusto Cezar; do Nascimento, Debora Cardoso
Article Title: Model for determination of costs for agribusiness of the ostrich breeding.
Author Keywords: Agribusiness; Cost Management; Ostrich breeding segment
Abstract: The dynamics of the business world demands the updating of the managerial practices of the rural enterprises, and it is also a fundamental truth in the effort to reach satisfactory results. Given the relevance of the knowledge on cost management and the gap in the literature in the field of ostrich breeding agribusiness, the goal of this paper is to propose a model of cost assessment for the agribusiness in the state of Ceara, in Brazil, focusing on the ostrich breeding segment, whose activity consists of the incubation, raising, re-raising and fattening of the ostrich for slaughtering. This study is based on the variable costing method as an alternative to manage the stock and to the formation of cost, supporting management in the decision making process, and allowing the monitoring of the several phases in the formation of the breeding stock. It is an exploratory research, carried out through a single case study. For managerial purposes, the method proposed, through the analysis of the contribution margin, facilitates the management by bird category, which allows managers to have a more detailed control of the costs for the ostrich raising.

Authors: Pinheiro, PR; Schmidt, P; dos Santos, JL; Fernandes, LA
Author Full Names: Pinheiro, Paulo Roberto; Schmidt, Paulo; dos Santos, Jose Luiz; Fernandes, Luciane Alves
Article Title: The proposal of a sustainable pricing model for the tobacco activity of the south region of Brazil
Author Keywords: Pricing; Agribusiness; Conflicts; Tobacco culture; Opportunity cost
Abstract: The study is to develop an economic model of pricing to explain the perception of tobacco growers and tobacco companies in southern Brazil on the amount of overtime worked in the production cost negotiated between the parties in order to minimize the conflicts. To this end, an interpretation of concepts, nature and measurement of the existing business model and the review and analysis of key indicators to measure related to it, analyze existing pricing models and theoretical framework that can support the construction of a new model pricing the cost of the work of the growers.

Authors: Du, XD; Hayes, DJ; Mallory, ML
Author Full Names: Du, Xiaodong; Hayes, Dermot J.; Mallory, Mindy L.
Article Title: A Welfare Analysis of the US Ethanol Subsidy
Abstract: Based on an analytical model of multiple interconnected markets including corn, ethanol, gasoline, and transportation fuel, this study estimates the welfare changes for consumers and producers resulting from ethanol production and related support polices in 2007. The welfare estimation takes into account the fact that the ethanol program was implemented in a market that had already been distorted by other programs. The results suggest a total social cost of about $0.89 billion for given market parameters. We validate the model's underlying assumption and test for the results' sensitivity to assumed parameters.

Author Full Names: Tozer, Peter R.; Stokes, Jeffrey R.
Article Title: Investing in Perennial Pasture Improvement: A Real Options Analysis
Abstract: In investment analysis, uncertainty and irreversibility can undermine net present value (NPV) as a decision rule since the option to delay investment may have value. We apply the real option theory of investment to the pasture investment decision facing livestock producers in southwest Western Australia. In 2006, livestock producers thinned their herds as pasture availability dwindled due to extreme drought conditions. This left producers with a unique opportunity to either establish new perennial pastures for their cattle or utilize volunteer annual pasture and invest in more sheep breeders. In either case, large and irreversible investments fraught with multiple sources of uncertainty implies that one can gain useful insights by casting the investment problem in a real option context. The results suggest that required rates of return for each investment alternative are about 1% to 1.5% higher than standard NPV would suggest with sheep production having the lower required rate of return.

Authors: Welgacz, HT; Souza, A; del Corso, JM; Duclós, LC
Author Full Names: Welgacz, Hanna Tatarchenko; Souza, Alceu; Maia del Corso, Jansen; Duclos, Luiz Carlos
Article Title: Hidden costs in the operations of Brazilian exports of meat.
Author Keywords: Hidden costs; Export; Agricultural business
Abstract: This article describes the hidden costs on the export operations of Brazilian meat. Such costs do not appear explicitly in the accounting records and its measurement is not an easy task but they impact significantly the profitability of the business. The approach method of research used was a case study including interviews with executives from three exporting companies. It was concluded that does exists hidden costs on export transactions and, despite its difficulty of measurement, it is necessary to establish contingency plans to mitigate the impact of these costs in the profitability of the business.

Authors: Duarte, SL; Pereira, CA; Tavares, M; dos Reis, EA
Author Full Names: Duarte, Sergio Lemos; Pereira, Carlos Antonio; Tavares, Marcelo; dos Reis, Ernando Antonio
Article Title: Variable production costs of soybeans and its relationship to Gross revenue
Author Keywords: Agribusiness; Costs; Soy
Abstract: Soy has been of great importance in the national economy, since Brazil is the second largest producer. Based on this scenario, both the cost and management accounting are essential when providing control tools for farmers aiming the profitability increasing. This study aims to investigate the behavior of the production costs at operations and inputs of soybean in relation to gross revenue. For this, we used the cost data and gross receipts of Agrianual - Brazilian Yearbook of Agriculture, in the period from 1999 to 2008. We analyzed the cost variables using the Kolmogorov- Smirnov (Lilliefors) to verify the normality of the data. Subsequently, we calculated the Spearman correlation coefficient for data said not normal and Pearson correlation coefficient, when the data had normal distribution. The purpose of calculating these coefficients was to examine whether the cost variables were correlated linearly. After calculating the coefficient of determination, was defined how much of a cost variable is explained by the variable gross revenue. Moreover, we obtained the linear regression equation to ascertain the dependence between variables, along with the estimate standard error. The results shown were that certain variable cost of soybean production, presented linear and predicted correlation with gross revenue and other variables showed no linear correlation, therefore, were excluded from the analysis.

Authors: Benetti, JE; Fiorentin, M; Lavarda, CEF
Author Full Names: Benetti, Juliana Eliza; Fiorentin, Marlene; Facin Lavarda, Carlos Eduardo
Article Title: Budgetary process in an agribusiness company
Author Keywords: Budget; Elaboration; Implementation; Evaluation; Agribusiness
Abstract: The study aims to describe the budget process used in a large agribusiness company in the state of Santa Catarina. To achieve the goal became a theoretical incursion addressing the budget conceptual aspects, highlighting its relevance to the company, its benefits as well as presenting some criticisms, in addition to previous studies on the subject. The research is characterized as descriptive accomplished through a descriptive case study and qualitative approach research problem. Data collection was conducted through a questionnaire with open questions answered to budget process authority in the company searched. It appears that empirical evidence on two propositions study. We conclude, as regards the budget, elaboration, implementation and evaluation there is participation of middle and lower management and the company tends to use the budget by giving importance to the achievement of budget targets, with low emphasis on interpersonal relationships. However, it was found that there is not flexibility in the budget targets.

Authors: Clemente, A; Souza, A; Taffarel, M; Gerigk, W
Author Full Names: Clemente, Ademir; Souza, Alceu; Taffarel, Marines; Gerigk, Willson
Article Title: Profile of family farms and cost control in South-Central Region of Parana
Author Keywords: Cost Management; Cost Control; Family Farms; Costs in Agriculture
Abstract: Business management requires an adequate information base. The cost control is an indispensable source of information because the costs directly influence the results. The management in agriculture, particularly in family farm agriculture is characterized by a large shortage of formal decision-making and use of information technology. The decisions in this sector are often based solely on experience and intuition. The aim of this paper is to examine the cost controls in family agriculture of the South-Central Region of Parana and seek relationships that may exist between the socio-economic profiles of the properties and the control of different costs. Statistical analysis is based on a sample of 235 (two hundred and thirty-five) properties for which information was raised by means of a questionnaire. Cultures widely prevalent in the region are tobacco, corn, beans and soybeans. The results show that family farm agriculture of the South-Central Region of Parana is very homogeneous, the cost controls are weak and the variables that make up the socio-economic profile of the properties are not differentiating factors of the cost controls adopted.

Author Full Names: da Silva Macedo, Marcelo Alvaro; Lunga, Aloizio
Article Title: Bibliometric and critical mapping of the economical and financial viability analysis of agribusiness projects: an evaluation of the publication in the sober congress in the period 2006-2009.
Author Keywords: Economical and financial viability; Agribusiness; Bibliometric analysis
Abstract: This paper makes a bibliometric research of the publications in the SOBER congress in the years of 2006, 2007, 2008 e 2009, aiming to map and analyze critically the use of economical and financial viability techniques. In this way, this study has the intention to offer an overview of the studies made and make itself into a reference base to future studies. The results show a slight trend of increase in the number of articles using these tools in the agribusiness sector and a large number of authors with only one work, which could be pointing to this issue is being used by area, but not developed by it. The critical analysis revealed some problems such as the fact that most of the articles do not consider investment in the working capital and most of these do not show the cash flow used in the analysis, which complicates their understanding.

Authors: Martins, OS; do Bomfim, ET; de Menezes, JEC
Author Full Names: Martins, Orleans Silva; do Bomfim, Emanoel Truta; Cruz de Menezes, Jose Elinilton
Article Title: Cost management in agroindustry: the use of contribution margin in decision making of a company of dairy in Paraiba.
Author Keywords: Costs; Contribution margin; Decision process
Abstract: This study aimed to conduct an investigation on the use of contribution margin in the process of decision making from a dairy company midsize state of Paraiba. To do so, left a theoretical about the contribution margin and its relation to the decision process in business. In this sense, there was an exploratory study, using a case study, using documentary research to collect data and review to lift the state of the art of the subject and substantiate the findings of the research, an interview and visits in loco. In their results, we can observe that, despite the limitations inherent in the contribution margin and the data collected, it can assist managers in defining the mix of production and marketing policy of the company's products, because they provides consistent information concerning the actual contribution that each product provides the company's profit, indicating the most profitable sales territories for the company and where sales should be encouraged.

Authors: Souza, A; Pedro, JJ; da Silva, WV; Duclós, LC
Author Full Names: Souza, Alceu; Pedro, Jeferson Joao; da Silva, Wesley Vieira; Duclos, Luiz Carlos
Article Title: Production costs, risks and return expectations of the corn agribusiness in the north altiplane of Santa Catarina State/Brazil
Author Keywords: Investment Decision; Multindicator Methodology; Agribusiness
Abstract: This article evaluate the production cost, investment return and risk expectations associated with two corn production productivity strategies, 120 bags of 60 kg/hectare and 150 bags of 60 kg/hectare, in the north altiplane of Santa Catarina State in Brazil. Investment analysis techniques and estimation of the cash flow representative of both production strategies was used to generate two set of indicators. The first set of financial indicators is composed by Net Present Value, Net Present Value Equivalent per Period, Cost Benefit Index and Added Rate of Return on Investment. The second set of risk indicators is composed by Minimum Attractive Rate of Return / Internal Rate of Return, Payback/N, Management Risk and Business Risk. Productivity and price are treated as random variables to represent the uncertainty in the agro business activity. The results of the analysis showed a low level of rentability and a high risk for both productivity levels. The results obtained with Monte Carlo simulation showed that in 85% of the time, the Rate of Return on Investment for strategy of low productivity level surpass the Rate of Return on Investment for strategy of high productivity level.

Authors: Mergenthaler, M; Weinberger, K; Qaim, M
Author Full Names: Mergenthaler, Marcus; Weinberger, Katinka; Qaim, Matin
Article Title: Consumer Valuation of Food Quality and Food Safety Attributes in Vietnam
Abstract: Food systems in developing countries are currently undergoing a profound transformation toward high-value products. Appropriate policies are needed to guide this transformation, presupposing good understanding of consumer preferences. We analyze consumers' valuation of different vegetable attributes in metropolitan areas of Vietnam, using contingent valuation techniques and a mediation framework for two specific examples. Consumers are willing to pay an average price premium of 60% for Chinese mustard that is free of chemical residues and of 19% for different convenience attributes of potatoes. Income levels and media have positive impacts on the willingness to pay, partly mediated through consumer perceptions.

Authors: Roberts, MJ; Schimmelpfennig, D; Livingston, MJ; Ashley, E
Author Full Names: Roberts, Michael J.; Schimmelpfennig, David; Livingston, Michael J.; Ashley, Elizabeth
Article Title: Estimating the Value of an Early-Warning System
Abstract: An early-warning system generates economic value to the extent that it improves decision making. The value of the information hinges on the degree to which a timely response, aided by warnings, facilitates successful damage mitigation. USDA's Coordinated Framework for Soybean Rust includes a network of sentinel soybean plots and wild kudzu stands monitored by extension agents for the presence of soybean rust, a potentially recurring threat to the U.S. soybean crop since 2005. The linchpin in this early-warning system is a website that provides near real-time, county-level information on the location of the disease. We consider factors that may influence information value.

Article Title: Biases in Calculating Dumping Margins: The Case of Cyclical Products
Abstract: A dumping investigation involves comparing export prices with a normal value loosely defined as the price in the exporter's domestic market observed in the course of normal trade. However, domestic sales with prices below production costs are excluded from the computation of a normal value. The paper illustrates how price cycles affect the magnitude of estimated dumping margins. The empirical analysis focuses on Canadian hog exports to the United States and U.S. potato exports to Canada. The estimated period and amplitude of each price cycles result in average dumping margins for Canadian hogs and U.S. potato exports of 11.5% and 5.9%, respectively. Biases in dumping margins depend on the nature of the cycle, the period of investigation, and the average production cost estimate.

Author Full Names: Woolverton, Andrea E.; Sykuta, Michael E.
Article Title: Do Income Support Programs Impact Producer Hedging Decisions? Evidence from a Cross-Country Comparative
Keywords Plus: FUTURES MARKETS; COMMODITY FUTURES; RISK; PRICE; MANAGEMENT; OPTIONS; DEMAND
Abstract: This article provides a unique perspective to why U.S. producers' hedging practices are not consistent with the price-risk management literature. We conduct a formal test of income support program impacts with survey data from South Africa and the United States, which have different producer income support policies. We find that producing in a supported environment (U.S.) decreases hedging for preplanting and preharvest expected yields by 30.39% and 20.03%, respectively. This study raises issues for further inquiry regarding both comparative agricultural lending practices and the relative costs of price-risk management tools.

Authors: Rodrigues, W; Barbosa, GF; Almeida, A
Author Full Names: Rodrigues, Waldecy; Barbosa, Gislane Ferreira; Almeida, Alivinio
Article Title: Environmental cost benefit analysis of soybean production in areas of recent expansion in the Brazilian savanna: the case of Pedro Afonso-TO
Author Keywords: Environmental cost-benefit analysis; Soybean; Tillage
Abstract: This article aims to achieve an environmental cost - benefit analysis of technologies for planting in areas of recent expansion in the Brazilian savannas, with a case study of the city of Pedro Afonso - TO. For the evaluation of economic efficiency and environmental effectiveness of soybean uses the method of cost-benefit analysis environmental, considering aspects of economic profitability and environmental sustainability in agricultural technology approach. Therefore the indicators of economic efficiency of production of soybeans in Pedro Afonso - TO has been shown that the technologies in question are planting economically efficient, but with clear economic advantage for the till. Moreover, the environmental costs of tillage are much lower than the conventional tillage, which leads to better indicators of cost-benefit performance of tillage.

Authors: Feng, H; Jha, M; Gassman, P
Author Full Names: Feng, Hongli; Jha, Manoj; Gassman, Phil
Article Title: The Allocation of Nutrient Load Reduction across a Watershed: Assessing Delivery Coefficients as an Implementation Tool
Keywords Plus: OF-MEXICO HYPOXIA; SURFACE WATERS; LAND-USE; NITROGEN; SEDIMENT; POLICIES; TMDLS
Abstract: Delivery coefficients have long been used in economic analysis of policies that seek to address environmental problems like water pollution. However, the derivation and validity of delivery coefficients have not been examined carefully by empirical analyses. We derived estimates of delivery coefficients and then evaluated them as a bridge between complex simulation models and economic policies like water quality trading. We found that the allocations achieved outcomes that differed from intended water quality targets by less than 10% in most cases. For the least-cost allocation with heterogeneous costs, cost savings significantly outweighed deviations from water quality targets.

Authors: Beline, H; Megliorini, E; Slomski, VG; Pereira, AC
Author Full Names: Beline, Helinton; Megliorini, Evandir; Slomski, Vilma Geni; Pereira, Anisio Candido
Article Title: Soybean: unrealized income losses avoided during harvest.
Author Keywords: Soy; Avoidable wastes; Not realizable incomes
Abstract: The wastes occurred during the harvest cause a hard impact in the agricultural business. About the soy fields, recent researches indicate that half of this waste could be avoided, reducing the cost of production and resultant earning of the companies. The purpose of this article is to analyze the estimative of soy harvest field area of 2006/07 to 2007/08 and respective production, subsidy estimate the waste that could be avoided during the harvest, considerating tolerable levels of 60 Kg by hectare, accordant is the model adopted on USA e Brazil. This research was based in a bibliographic study to explain and analyze all sides, practical and theoretical around the investigate problem. It was checked that is possible expect and avoid these wastes during the harvest. Such wastes overcome the mark of 20,000 ton/year, that in money talks represent over R$ 1.000.000 mil/year. Conclude however that wastes when treated provide a production cost reduction, indicating execution and a positive impact on agricultural companies' earnings.

Authors: Cunha, MCF; Cavalcante, PRD; Prado, AGD; Silva, ACDE
Author Full Names: Freire Cunha, Marilia Caroline; da Nobrega Cavalcante, Paulo Roberto; da Silva Prado, Alexsandro Goncalves; da Cunha e Silva Filho, Augusto Cezar
Article Title: Process analysis of cost management of agents that comprise the production chain of culture of sisal in the State of Paraiba
Author Keywords: Sisal; Management of costs; Agribusiness; Productive chain
Abstract: In Brazil, sisal is grown exclusively in the Northeast, especially in Bahia and Paraiba, and stands out for its relevance in the socio-economic context in low-income locations. This exploratory study aimed to analyze the process of cost management agents of the productive chain of the culture of sisal in the state of Paraiba. The data were collected through a questionnaire next to the components of the production chain, obtaining a sample of 86 respondents. It was found that most agents of the supply chain focuses on growers and shredders (95%) and those working for more than 20 years (83%) in the segment. It was found that 60% doesn't understand the supply chain costs, 76% doesn't use cost information in their activities and 96% doesn't use tool for calculating costs. The results showed instability in the understanding of the concepts/tools cost in the production chain, especially as growers and grinders. This situation can be justified by the low profitability of the segment that discourages the exercise of the activity. The survey revealed that the inadequacies are more present than the adjustments to the understanding of the concepts/tools for cost/costing.

Article Title: Economic profitability of the production of biodiesel from castor in the Tocantins State
Author Keywords: biodiesel; castor; family farming
Abstract: The paper analyzes the current conditions of economic feasibility of production of castor oil on family farms to produce biodiesel in the state of Tocantins ( Brazil). As a result, the yield earned by the producers of castor in Tocantins is insufficient for the minimum conditions of economic viability of the culture. Moreover, the farmers responsible for this production are few in number, dispersed by the Tocantins State and away from the plant. The company produces biodiesel has shown little ability to coordinate the production chain and the agents. Although there is an institutional environment consisting of regulations and government policies, the company produces biodiesel showed no concerns with the improvement of conditions for the productivity of farmers partners to the effective use of castor oil for biofuel production.

Authors: Bonacim, CAG; Gaio, LE; Ambrozini, MA
Author Full Names: Grespan Bonacim, Carlos Alberto; Gaio, Luiz Eduardo; Ambrozini, Marcelo Augusto
Article Title: Financial leverage and tangibility of assets of Brazilian companies of agribusiness in the post-real plan period
Author Keywords: Asset tangibility; Financial leverage; Autoregressive vector
Abstract: This paper aims to study the relationship between the debt level and the asset structure of Brazilian companies of the agribusiness sector, since it is considered a current and relevant discussion: to evaluate the mechanisms for fund-raising and guarantees. The methodology of Granger's Causality test and Autoregressive Vectors was used to conduct a comparative analysis, applied to a financial database of companies with open capital of Brazilian agribusiness, in particular the agricultural sector and Fisheries and Food and Beverages in a period of 10 years (1997-2007) from quarterly series available in the database of Economatica(R). The results demonstrated that changes in leverage generate variations in the tangibility of the companies, a fact that can be explained by the large search of funding secured by fiduciary transfer of fixed assets, which facilitates access to credit by business of the Agribusiness sector, increasing the payment time and lowering interest rates.

Authors: de Oliveira, AR; Calegário, CLL; Gaio, LE; Bonacim, CAG
Author Full Names: de Oliveira, Andre Ribeiro; Leal Calegario, Cristina Lelis; Gaio, Luiz Eduardo; Grespan Bonacim, Carlos Alberto
Article Title: Economic and financial analysis of the Brazilian fuel market
Author Keywords: Economics of the Transaction Costs; Producing chain; Cachaca
Abstract: The cachaca is a product typically Brazilian and of extreme importance for the country, whether in historical context, socio-cultural or economic, and a significant sector for generating employment and income. This work aims to analyze the characteristics of the productive chain of cacha a in Minas Gerais from the perspective of Economic Affairs of Transaction Costs, stressing it is both institutional aspects that may limit how much support the development of enterprises, aspects of production and processing of sugar cane - of-sugar, and aspects of marketing and consumption, inhibitors or drivers of the market in question. It appears that the production of cacha a is not a productive chain organized, with clear definition of their ties and exchanges. In general, to realize that, currently, the production of cacha a, still is undergoing a profound revision in its concepts and entrepreneurial initiatives, among them the stance of the new investors in the agribusiness of cachaca, which aim at quality and profit, leaving aside the idea that the activity would simply be to supplement the budget of ownership and maintenance of agricultural facilities.

Authors: Carmo, CRS; Lima, IG; Oliveira, R; Oliveira, LFME
Author Full Names: Souza Carmo, Carlos Roberto; Lima, Igor Gabriel; Oliveira, Renata; Melo e Oliveira, Luiz Fernando
Article Title: Mathematical modeling in cost management: a study based on cost behavior in poultry production in Minas Gerais
Author Keywords: Mathematical modeling; Cost prediction; Poultry
Abstract: According to the Ministry of Agriculture, Brazilian agribusiness is responsible for 33% of domestic growth, 42% of total exports and 37% of employment in the country. In this context, Embrapa's swine and bird unit calculates and informs, monthly, the costs of poultry for slaughtering in three types of breeding (manual, automatic and under climatic conditions), in ten Brazilian states. Based on the costing records provided by Embrapa, this work aims at conceiving a mathematical modeling proposal which is able to achieve linearity in cost behavior in relation to the quantity of poultry bred for slaughtering, by means of manual production, in the state of Minas Gerais. Secondly, it aims at propitiating the constitution of a planning tool for costs which are associated with that economical activity. After the proper theoretical support as well as statistical use of linear regression, it has been verified that the researched modeling is satisfactory for production estimates between 20,000 and 25,000 units, since it is admitted a margin of error of +/- 11%.

Article Title: Costs of Organic Milk Production on US Dairy Farms
Abstract: The impact of organic participation on milk production costs is evaluated using data from a nationwide survey of dairy operations. Organic dairies have estimated costs about $5 to $8 per cwt higher than conventional dairies. They also receive an average milk price premium of $6.69 per cwt in 2005. Production costs are estimated to be only $3 to $4 per cwt higher among pasture-based dairies. Results suggest that small conventional dairies may consider converting to the organic approach, but startup organic dairies are not likely unless they can enter at a much larger scale than the industry norm or can utilize pasture as a primary dairy feed source.

Author Full Names: Tonsor, Glynn T.; Featherstone, Allen M.
Article Title: Production Efficiency of Specialized Swine Producers
Keywords Plus: NONPARAMETRIC FRONTIER MODELS; DATA ENVELOPMENT ANALYSIS; TECHNICAL EFFICIENCY; FARMS
Abstract: This research provides an efficiency evaluation of swine firms by specialization type providing estimates of technical, allocative, scale, and overall efficiency separately for farrow-to-finish, farrow-to-feeder, feeder-to-finish, farrow-to-weanling, and weanling-to-feeder operations. Results indicate variation in efficiency measures both across and within operation specializations. This suggests optimal adjustments for enhancing efficiency may not be homogeneous across the industry and may vary across specializations. The analysis also implies that future analyses of the swine industry must carefully and individually consider the diverse specializations comprising the industry. These findings are important in further understanding the rapid change occurring in the swine industry in the form of increased production specialization.

Authors: Zhen, C; Taylor, JL; Muth, MK; Leibtag, E
Author Full Names: Zhen, Chen; Taylor, Justin L.; Muth, Mary K.; Leibtag, Ephraim
Article Title: Understanding Differences in Self-Reported Expenditures between Household Scanner Data and Diary Survey Data: A Comparison of Homescan and Consumer Expenditure Survey
Keywords Plus: DEMAND; INFORMATION; MODELS; ERROR; CONSUMPTION; ESTIMATOR; OVERCOME; PRICES; IMPACT; FRESH
Abstract: Household scanner data contain rich information on household demographics and transactions in actual markets over a long time period. To more fully understand the characteristics of these data, we conducted an analysis to determine whether household expenditures in the Nielsen Homescan panel are similar to the Bureau of Labor Statistic's Consumer Expenditure Diary Survey. We found that many differences in reported expenditures across the two datasets can be explained by such household demographics as female head, income, and household size, for example. The largest degrees of discrepancies across datasets occur for food categories containing more random-weight foods without universal product codes.

Author Full Names: Duke, Joshua M.; Awokuse, Titus O.
Article Title: Assessing the Effect of Bilateral Collaborations on Learning Outcomes
Abstract: Despite recent interest in the effects of student-driven collaborations on learning outcomes, little or no empirical investigations examine the potential benefits from collaboration between instructors of separate, but related, courses. This study proposes a learning intervention that explicitly accounts for interdependencies across courses and extends the traditional definition of collaborative learning to include the synthesis of teaching and learning in four courses through bilateral, group activities between instructors and among students. A student-performance measure assesses the intervention. Statistical results suggest that the collaborative learning intervention improved student-writing performance.

Authors: Grzebieluckas, C; Campos, LMD; Bornia, AC; Selig, PM
Author Full Names: Grzebieluckas, Cleci; de Souza Campos, Lucila Maria; Bornia, Antonio Cezar; Selig, Paulo Mauricio
Article Title: Integrating the environmental cost of methane (CH4) and carbon credits (RECs) in the analysis of agricultural investment: a study in the Brazilian cerrado
Author Keywords: Economic viability; Traditional versus sustainable agriculture; Carbon
Abstract: The aim of this study was to analyze investment mangaba planting and dairy farming, including the analysis, the environmental cost of methane and carbon credits from plants. The survey was conducted in two farms, one that has as main crop planting native fruits of the cerrado and other dairy farming, both in the municipality of the State of Goias Arenopolis The time horizon of the study was 10 years and the techniques used were Net Present Value - NPV, Internal Rate of Return - IRR and Cost Benefit Analysis - CBA. The two activities are economically viable because they have had internal rates of return higher than those determined by the study was 10%. The NPV of R $ mangaba was 58.040/ha and dairy farming was R $ 7,355. The incorporation of carbon credits in the analysis of fruit trees to an increment of 0.65% in the NPV for each hectare planted mangaba. In the analysis of dairy farming, including the environmental cost of methane (CH4) generating a reduction of 10.60% / ha in NPV.
